text: children or a disability.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: It's so wrong.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Yes, but who has the power to stop this?
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: You do.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Each of us has the power.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: The law is on your side.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: It's illegal for landlords to discriminate because of race, color, religion, sex, national origin, disability, or familial status.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: If you suspect that you have experienced housing discrimination, file a complaint with HUD immediately so we can investigate it.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Fair housing is your right.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Use it.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: To learn more, visit HUD.gov slash fairhousing.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: That's HUD.gov slash fairhousing.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: A public service message from HUD in partnership with the National Fair Housing Alliance.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Welcome back to the Florida Roundtable.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: I'm Bill Mick along with Florida Secretary of State Cord Byrd.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Mr. Secretary, appreciate you taking the time.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: It's good to have you along this weekend.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Great to be back.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Let's talk real quickly about the wrap up of an election.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: There is testing of the election tabulation equipment, logic and accuracy testing in every county.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: And I guess you guys, you maintain those records.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Those come into you after the fact.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Let's talk about your confidence level and how Florida conducts these elections right now.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Right.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Great question.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And Florida has 24, 25 years of working on this and getting it right to where we are the best in the country.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Do not take me back to hanging chads.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Right.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So you nailed it.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So we've had a lot of time to get this right.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And I do have tremendous confidence.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And one of the things that we do in Florida that I wish other states would adopt is.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: is that no voting system, meaning something that accepts a ballot, can be used by a county unless it's first certified by the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So we have a team of people that'll break the machines down, try to break them, try to mess with them, try to make them operate improperly.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So before any supervisor can use a system, it's first certified by the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And then you mentioned logic and accuracy testing.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: That's a public event where the supervisors
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: take a random sampling of the machines, run sample ballots through them, ensure that the ballots that go through or the ballots that are the results that are tabulated, that's open to the public.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And then once again, at the end of the day, we have the paper ballot and our state law says that the paper ballot is the best evidence of the voter's intent.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So if we do have one of those close elections and we need to go to the tape, so to speak, we have those paper ballots.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And so that's why I'm confident in the outcome.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: In Brevard County and other counties around the state, I'm not sure if it's every county, we have this clear audit system that after the ballots are run through the actual tabulation equipment, this is a totally separate, not online system at all, not connected to any of the voting mechanism, but it basically, they run the ballots through that and verify by a separate system that everything was right.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: No, you're absolutely right.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: It's a great system.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So we have about 30 of the counties that are using that system now.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: We're proposing that, hoping that the legislature will fund a grant to allow all 67 counties to be able to utilize this system.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And as you mentioned, it's completely separate.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So it's a check on the tabulators.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So we have the logic and accuracy testing.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: We go through that with the machines.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Then we have clear audit, which is a 100% audit of the race.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: We know after 2020, you know, auditing of the elections was a big issue.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Now we would have with this system.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So for Brevard County, you have a 100 percent audit in place, which once again should give confidence to the voters that the tabulations are correct.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Most certainly.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: One of the complaints we hear around the country, I don't know how much Florida is impacted by this, but the threat of, if not actual, non-citizen voting.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Some places around the country allow non-citizens to vote in local elections and the like.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Is that becoming an issue?
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Is that an issue that you hear about a lot?
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: I do.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: I mean, I would say that nationwide it is the number one election integrity topic currently out there.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And here's the challenge.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And I was back in May, I testified before a congressional committee about non-citizen voting.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And the real issue we have is with federal law that prevents states from doing certain list maintenance activities and getting the information we need on non-citizens before they're added to the voter roll.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So, for example,
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: U.S.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Constitution says the federal government has complete authority over who becomes a naturalized citizen.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: We had ninety four thousand Floridians become naturalized or non-citizens become naturalized in Florida just in 2023 alone.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Wow.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: That's a big number.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And so what happens because of federal law, if the person fills out the voter application, voter registration form,
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: If they perjure themselves and say they're a U.S.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: citizen and turn it in, we have to do the verification on the back end.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: We're doing that work every single day.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: We're getting information from a variety of places.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: But before we remove someone from the voter rolls, we've got to make sure we have the right, you know, John Smith.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And we don't what we don't want to do is remove someone who is a U.S.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: citizen who has become naturalized.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And sometimes that happens.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And I'm happy to say that Congress listened to us.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: One of my proposals actually made it into the bill.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: It was ended up being amended.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: That would require the federal government to send to the states every month a list of who becomes a naturalized citizen.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And then we can take that list and then run that against our voter registration database.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Unfortunately, it's stalled in the in the U.S.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Senate.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And you can imagine the reason why.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: But the good news is that Congress is listening.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: They know it's a problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And we're going to continue doing everything legally that we can do.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: to remove non-citizens from the voter rolls because every every non-citizen that votes you know cancels out the vote of a citizen so this is really important but we need the help of the feds and i'm happy to say that they are finally paying attention i'm glad to hear that that they are listening to people like you that are in a position of managing these elections across the state and across the country and actually talk to the people on the ground
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: I had a situation a few years ago where our former supervisor of elections was being called to Tallahassee to testify to a Senate or House committee regarding election law.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: And they take the six hour drive and they're told to get one minute to speak.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: You're not listening to the people if you don't give them time to tell you what's going on.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: I would like to see our legislature get the same give the same reception to supervisors that you got when you went to Washington.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Yeah, and I will say, you know, they do ask questions.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: You know, I serve with many of them.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: They contact me all the time asking questions.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: What can they do to improve?
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: I mean, they want to get it right.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: They got to get elected.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: They're going to be on the ballot again.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Yeah.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: They are on the ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Yeah, all of them.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: They're all up this cycle.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So, yeah, I know that sometimes it's frustrating for people when they come to a committee with limited time.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: They don't get a full hearing.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: But I know the supervisors are here during the legislative session.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: They're making the rounds, going and talking to legislators.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And we work hard to try to be on the same page and get it right to make sure that we have the best election code in the country.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: You mentioned that federal cooperation you're looking for.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Another area where I would think would be emphasized is a good system for ensuring.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: The people who snowboard or people who live here part of the year and split residency, whatever it may be, aren't voting in multiple states in a federal election.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: That seems pretty hard to track down right now.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: And in some cases I'm aware of, the local prosecutors won't handle an election fraud case as if it's something serious when you've got someone who's voted in, say, New Mexico and Florida.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Right.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Well, that's why the legislature and the governor's leadership a few years ago created the Office of Election Crimes and Security, which is within the Department of State, something that I oversee.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And so we have a dedicated unit that is looking at these double voters in multiple states.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: We've had several prosecutions.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Just a few weeks ago, two Florida appellate courts confirmed that the statewide prosecutor has jurisdiction all over the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So if we have a local prosecutor who's maybe not interested or doesn't care about prosecuting these cases, the statewide prosecutor can.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So we take our election law seriously in Florida.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: We have a unit dedicated to enforcing them in partnership with the FDLE.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So once again, those are some of the things that we're doing when it's not, quote unquote, election season that we're still doing.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: constantly talking to other states, looking at the voter rolls, comparing and seeing when someone moves out of the state of Florida and we know we get information that they're a registered voter and in the other state we're contacting that state saying, hey, did you know
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: That person has moved to your state or vice versa.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Somebody moves into the state and they say, hey, I came from New York and we're contacting them saying, you know, hey, this person is now here.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: They've registered to vote.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: You can remove them off of your role.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So those are some of the things that we do in the off season.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And even during the season of elections is is getting that doing that voter list maintenance activity.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Forgive me for a political question during an elections administration session here, but would a national voter registration make sense in that regard?
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: You know, the question then becomes who houses the information?
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And I would not be confident in the federal government housing that database.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Can understand that, sure.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So why it seems your logic is not incorrect.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: I would be very hesitant to put all of that database of all 50 states with all of the registered voters in the hands of D.C.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: For all of our
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: The warts that our system has in 50 different jurisdictions, you know, with different philosophies on elections and why that can cause frustrations.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: I think that the the the evil that the potential evil that could come from having it all in one place is outweighed by.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: you know, sometimes what we see happen in other states.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Sure.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: How difficult is it to run down that person who's double voted in a couple of states?
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: I know the ERIC system is no longer in play for the state of Florida that lets you validate with some states instantly.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: So that sounds like investigation time there.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: It does.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And we're entering into memorandum of understanding with other states to help us do that.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: I mean, let's, you know,
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: To be fair, you know, Eric, all 50 states weren't in Eric.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So you still only had a certain segment of the country that was in it.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: California and New York, two of the four largest states were not in Eric.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So it was an imperfect system.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: But we have the states that are cooperative with with us.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And most of your most of the people that are going between states tend to be your neighboring states.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So, you know, Georgia, Louisiana.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: I've got to end it there for the moment.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: We'll be back with Secretary of State Cord Byrd on the Florida Roundtable.

speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: Welcome back to the Florida Roundtable.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Bill Mick with Secretary of State Cord Byrd.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: And Mr. Secretary, let's talk about the tight races that we've... The governor had one with his first election.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: There are automatic triggers for recounts.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Let's talk about those for a minute.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Should we have a tight race in any of these jurisdictions in Florida?
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Right.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So my first suggestion is that everybody win big.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: That's what I tell all candidates.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And if you can win big, but sometimes that doesn't happen.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: You know, I was part of the I was one of the lawyers during the recount in 2018 in Duval County.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: But under state law, if you are within one half of one percent, it automatically triggers a machine recount.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So they they recount the same ballots and see if we get the same number.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: If then after that machine recount, it's within a quarter percent, then there is a hand recount of over and under votes.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So does that make sense?
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So if the machines, if somebody would they then look at over and under the canvassing board looks at those and then there's a hand recount of those votes.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: to see if there's any further discrepancy.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So overvotes being too many names marked on that particular race in a ballot, undervotes meaning none were marked in that race.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Correct, correct.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And you'd be amazed at the different ways in which voters mark ballots.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Another one of my admonitions is please fill in the ovals correctly.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: No stray marks.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Don't circle parties because that leads to potentially recounts where then you have a canvassing board trying to divine the voter, you know, the voter intent.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: What were they certainly?
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: I'm sorry, while we're there, let's talk about voters in the polling place, either early voting or on Election Day.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: They make a mistake marking their ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: There are ways to correct it on that ballot, but they can also turn that ballot in and get a second one once that first one's destroyed.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Right.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: You get two mulligans.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So you get your first ballot, and you get up to two more ballots if you make a mistake.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: After that, then you're out of luck.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Yeah.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And those and those ballots are destroyed.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: If you make a mistake, you take that up to the clerk.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: The clerk will spoil what we call spoil the ballot, meaning destroy it.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: We have we have procedures in place for every polling place.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So that's done consistently throughout the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: It's done in front of the voter.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So the mistaken or spoiled ballot is destroyed.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And then are you made where it can't be counted?
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And then they're given an alternate replacement ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Outstanding.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Now, what if a candidate, for some reason, has a challenge in an election?
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Do they have the ability to request or demand, in any case, a recount?
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Only if it falls within those mandatory recount numbers.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: I mean, a candidate does not have the right to demand a recount, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Okay.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So if they, if they allege some nefarious behavior by an opponent or maybe a mistake by a supervisor of elections office somewhere, that's lawsuit territory at that point?
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Correct.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: That would then be, that would then be their, their recourse would then be to the courts.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: You've been in some of those battles, at least, uh, back in what, 2000, as I recall?
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Yeah.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Yeah.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Yeah.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So I was, uh, I was a young lawyer back in the 2000 in Palm Beach County.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So, uh,
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Yeah, tangentially involved in that and drafting motions and all that good stuff.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: You've got two advocating sides at that point, both of them trying to present their best argument.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: How much of those end up being focused in actual law or opinion as to why my guy should win?
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Yeah, I mean, that's certainly a lot of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And when I give talks around the state, if you're trying to litigate your way to victory, that's usually a losing proposition.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: The courts are very reluctant to change the outcome or the results of an election.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And I think rightfully so.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: We don't want
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Take the U.S.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Supreme Court, for example.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: You don't want non-elected or unelected lawyers in robes deciding who our president's going to be typically.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: It's not a good thing for a republic.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So the courts are reluctant to get involved.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: But there is that recourse.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And if there's evidence that shows that there was malfeasance or the election code wasn't followed properly, then they would have recourse.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: I know that you're able to meet on occasion with the Association of Supervisors of Elections as they come together at various times.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Any concerns been raised by them as we come into this election?
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Well, we're in this election season.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: Right.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Only the ones I think that we've discussed, making sure that voters are fully informed, knowing where their polling place is, if they want to vote by mail ballot, that they put their request in, that they have the updated signature on file.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: So one, just making sure that voters have good information.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Obviously,
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: In the event that we have a storm or a weather event that interferes with voters' ability to vote, that we have contingency plans in place.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: But I think for the most part, we have a wonderful working relationship with the supervisors.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: They're all elected by the people in their county, so they're accountable.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: They care about this.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: They live in those communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: They want this system to work right.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: And I think they, for the most part, all do a really, really good job.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Secretary of State Cord Byrd is with us here on the Florida Roundtable.
speaker: SPEAKER_13

text: One more segment to go.
speaker: SPEAKER_13
